commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Something you might have when trying to move quickly  (4)(4)
2. Job done on one's hands and feet  (4)(4)
3. Shorthand for a stance  (3)
4. React to something moving, say  (3)
5. When mating typically occurs  (3)(4)


FIRE SALE
MANI PEDI
IMO
CRY
END GAME
Solved in 8:17 without looking at hints. Yes, Monday puzzles are quite easy.

Nice debut and puzzle!

Thanks, Katherine!

Congrats Kathryn on your debut! This was a fine Monday puzzle and very smooth fill. Surprised the editors didn’t throw you a bone and keep MIT in your ELITE clue. But I gotta tell you lately the ELITE crossword college for constructors is Harvey Mudd. But keep it up, MIT may catch up.
My only nit is FASTFOODS. Yes I know you needed it for symmetry and technically it’s probably acceptable, but does anyone really say this plural? “I’m going to go get some fast foods”? “Burgers and fries are  fast foods”? Same with “fares” for that matter. This is your debut so I’m giving you a pass, but I might not be so kind on your second puzzle, which I hope will be soon. ; )  (This is all tongue in cheek, seriously, well done).
49-Down is wrong. DIM SUM is what you get when your calculator battery dies on you.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/10/12/monday-october-13-2025/#ny
Wow - very surprised that 48-down is considered Monday level.  It's indeed a gimme for academics, but I wouldn't have thought that it was for non-academics.
“I can’t believe I mis-spelled the tree whose name comes phonetically between “tee” and “vee”, he said, sheepishly.
I did this crossword earlier today and...it disappeared and I just completed it again. ??

Fun! HOTPOCKET fit in the microwave bfast and RAMENNOODLES in the dorm room, but fortunately my goofs didn't last too long. I have no idea why Hot Pockets came to mind-- I've never even eaten one. I usually eat beans and greens for breakfast, my own weird habit. Must have been Jim Gaffigan whispering in my ear! https://youtu.be/N-i9GXbptog?si=akvruc7lwf3NKmsG
Such a fun Monday! Have never heard of LEMMA. Maybe if I had, I would have done better in math! Hope y’all have a great Monday. Thanks, Katherine!

TIL:
This old math major learned that there are lemmas in linguistics. Fortunately for me, the clue was written by a fellow STEM type.
Very fun puzzle! Congratulations on your debut, Katherine!

Very enjoyable puzzle.    But could I ask if others are having issues playing on an IPhone?    This area of Wordplay and comments is not available, all of a sudden.    I can access this on my laptop but not on my phone.    I sent a request, but so far only an AI robot answer.   Maybe Monday they will fix it.

Many years ago, when the lottery was starting in Iowa, a Cedar Rapids disc jockey became well known throughout the state. For a few months, he had interviews daily with two people. He introduced them as a country singer named SLIM  and a female nun.

TODAY you will be hearing from two people who will discuss your chance of winning the lottery- SLIM and Nun

Everyone struggling with LEMMA, where as my sticking point was SIES. Spanish is one of the biggest gaps in my knowledge when it comes to NYT games. It just isn't taught here. Give me Japanese or Indonesian and I'll cruise through.
Just FYI, INSTANTRAMEN has the same number of letters as ramenNoodles.

Fantastic debut, Katherine. I loved seeing ESQUE in the puzzle. I’m partial to the letter Q (my maiden name also starts with a Q). I never learned the second verse of Yankee Doodle, so TIL HASTY PUDDING. Nice, tight theme. Looking forward to seeing more from you ☺️

Happy Monday!
Great puzzle, Katherine! Trucked through this one with ease, and it was very fun to fill! Keep up the great work! :)
One for the pedants. The “correct” (Greek) plural for LEMMA is lemmata, ask the octopodes.

"For the record, I originally clued 3-Down as “Like MIT and Harvard,” but alas, the editors had other plans."

Oh those snooty editors. I bet they never could have gotten into MIT!

Congratulations on your debut, Ms. Xiong! Very nicely done.

I very much enjoyed the past few days of puzzles, and today's has kept up the momentum. 

The only thing is that just yesterday I streamed "The Taste of Things" (starring Juliette Binoche) and it centers on culinary arts that are a far cry from today's FAST FOODS; very much the opposite, in fact. 

HASTY PUDDING sounded familiar and I can't put my finger on it, whether it's because it's been mentioned in The Great British Baking Show or something else. 

All in all, and great romp. Thank you, Ms. Xiong!

i had this one so fast until i got stuck on 70A and 64D ("lemma" and "tam"), so i just googled it because i wasn't going to guess every letter with the popup telling me i'm close every time. by the way does anyone have a recommendation on crossword games i can play on my phone or computer that are good practice?
When life gives you a cheeky Monday you just gotta make LEMMA NAYS.

Extra fun for us foreigners today, trying to guess what Americans eat. AFAIK the diet includes:

Oreos
Rolos 
Oreos
General Tso’s chicken
Eggo
Rye
Aioli
Eel
Ahi tuna
Various -ades 
Oreos again

What did I miss?
All, for nothing? Whatevs?  SRSLY?

Such a nice crossword for Monday. I was stumped only by LEMMA, at first I didn't believe it was a word. I had lake instead of MALL, it seemed possible. 

A promising debut!
Fun theme , but quite easy making this just right to start the week.

I know people get zesty when you talk about the relative difficulty of Monday puzzles, but I do think this was one of the trickier solves, with ULTA and LEMMA being a bit more obscure than one might normally expect on a Monday (I didn't know either). Still, a fun puzzle!
Sam Corbin, how do you do it, day after day?  Come through with a perfect photo pun of the headline, and gild it with another lovely pun in the caption?  You are a treasure.
Congratulations, Katherine! A clever and well constructed NYT debut!

Fun Monday puzzle. Fairly smooth solve but I was almost done when I finally caught on to the theme. That's always a nice touch. Looking forward to more from Ms. Xiong. Appropriate puzzle find today - a Monday from November 27, 1995 by Gregory E. Paul. Theme answers in that one - all straightforwardly clued: RAPIDTRANSIT QUICKDRAW FASTBREAK HASTYPUDDIING Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/27/1995&g=57&d=A .....

This lovely theme is not only tight, but adds two worthy answers to the NYT oeuvre, INSTANT RAMEN and QUICK OATS.

It also echoes last Monday’s theme, in that both words of the theme answer are used in service to the theme, rather than just the first or last word.  Last Monday’s theme was also food related.

Sweet serendipities today.  Five palindromes and a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (NAÏVE).  Also, YEW crossing YOU.  Not to mention the DIM SUM connection, with DIM being a kinda ANTONYM of NEON, and SUM relating nicely to [Uno + dos + tres].

Finally, my day is made because I successfully guessed the revealer that I had left blank, a skill I’m weak at and work on all the time, rarely succeeding. 

So, for me, a goody-filled box today.  Congratulations on your debut, Katherine, and thank you!

Ditto on macaroni, Sam.

Lemma tell you sumptin' I enjoyed the puzzle!

Keep 'em comin'!

Simple and solid Monday puzzle. Liked the pairing of "ATTA girl!" and ITSABOY! 

Congratulations on the debut.

When our boys were teens, 
I got tired of spending *so* much money
and two days cooking Thanksgiving dinner
to watch them eat rolls and macaroni and cheese.

So we called a family meeting.
We all love dim sum?
Agreed.
Dim sum it is!

I was thrilled. Everyone was so happy!
(The servers looked confused,
assuming we just didn’t know what day it was.)

It was delicious. Simple. Peaceful.

On the drive home, 
our younger son said, 
“So, we’re just having our real Thanksgiving 
dinner tomorrow?”

He actually cared.
It meant something.

We both said, “Yep!”
And scrambled that Friday to find a half-turkey 
and all the fixins and we set the table
and did the whole thing.

They ate rolls. 
But with gravy. And stuffing!

That was the day our tough teenaged boys
outed themselves as sentimental,
family-tradition-loving softies.

But, tonight? 
Dim sum.

Here's Jill Clayburgh sketching the proof of the "Snake Lemma", a standard result in homological algebra. As scenes depicting modern mathematics go, this one is quite well done. From "It's My Turn" (1980). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aXBNPjrvx-I
On a stormy, flood prone Monday, this one SHONE.  Great debut and thanks.

Easy, breezy Monday puzzle. Perfectly fine,if not terribly exciting, in line with the way Mondays usually are. A nice debut.

Despite living in NY and environs for more than half my life, I had never had dim sum until a Chinese couple, whom we'd Airbnb -hosted at our home several times when their daughter was an exchange student at the school around the corner from us, came across from the mainland and took us to an very upscale Dim Sum restaurant when we were visiting Hong Kong. I was hooked from then on!

On another note, a big thank you to those who wished me a happy birthday yesterday. Very much appreciated!

Oooh! One more late puzzle find. This one was a simply incredible feat of construction. A Sunday from April 13, 2003 by Charles Deber with title: "What am I?" Five theme answers in that one - three of them 21 letters and the other two 20 letters. Here are the first four of those theme answers with their clues: "If I have ___ :" SEVENTYTWODARKSQUARES "... and I am ___ :" TWENTYONEBYTWENTYONE "... and I am ___ :" MODERATELYCHALLENGING "... and I have ___ :" ONEHUNDREDFORTYWORDS And you might be able to guess more or less what the last theme clue and answer must be like. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/13/2003&g=102&d=A ....

FAST FOODS again?  We have to be in desperate circumstances (or on the road) to cave in... but even McD has salads these days.  

Two clues en Español!  
Ms. Xiong includes DIMSUM, Mao, LOTUS, even IVORY... all of Chinese origin...
But CAVIAR at the same meal as RAMEN?

There's not much to do on a Monday morning.  Sunday afternoon ended in a welter of confusion and lengthy wait times in ER for DHubby (he's fine, he's fine!  Dx...severe hematoma blamed on 3 x weekly baby aspirin....only 2 x weekly from now on.  Swelling already down somewhat.)

Lemma add myself to the LEMMA-ignorant. 

I was unaware of HASTY PUDDING outside the realm of Harvard. (I had “figgy pudding” here. Must be all the Christmas decorations I’m already seeing.) “Ramen noodles” also slowed me down. 

This was pretty chewy for a Monday, which is not a bad thing! Who else is hungry?
Congratulations, Katherine!  “All, for nothing, e.g” is an excellent clue.  And you used EKED and NAYS like an old pro!

This one took me longer than usual for a Monday.  Top center area felt a bit confusing just because I felt TODAY was a strange answer to "Now" because it represents a broader period of time than just the current moment, I am not familiar with QUICK OATS, DO A SET was a bit awkwardly phrased, and OHO feels like a reach to call it a word.
Is it just me or has the link from the puzzle to the Wordplay column changed? I am confused!

My grandmother made something called Indian pudding, which is HASTY PUDDING, but made with cornmeal in place of the oats. Delicious! It takes a few hours to cook down to the right consistency, so not exactly FAST FOOD. I've never had the traditional English version, but I knew the song.

Oh... and what the heck - one more puzzle find. A Tuesday from September 16, 1997 by Christopher page. Seven answers in that one - all straightforwardly clued. And - there was no 'reveal' in the puzzle. DROMEDARY STATUARY MAORI HAILMARY TIPPERARY APOTHECARY HEREDITARY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/16/1997&g=17&d=A ...
Congratulations on a well-constructed debut, Katherine-- looking forward to seeing more from you!

Tough for a Monday, with some foreign language words and especially the combination of a TAM and LEMMA, neither of which I knew before today’s puzzle (despite having survived multiple levels of calculus in college… ok so I must have forgotten what those helpful theorems are called). 

But also when crossed up with Dim Sum (is it “sum” or “sun”, I couldn’t recall as I was struggling to finish a Monday puzzle?!) this was not as easy as many Mondays.
LEMMA crossing TAM on a Monday is… a choice

Part 1 of 2:

I get a hint of today’s puzzle constructor being an expectant mom. Just a feeling.

Quick ramen story, maybe one or two of the Veteran solvers here can relate:

My first tour of duty in Korea was in 1979. We did our training in the mountains that dwarf Tongduchŏn (TDC, to those in the know), in preparation for our 30-day rotations in the DMZ. My weapon (not by choice) was the M-60, a most devastating weapon with awesome firepower. Our rucksacks were packed for the usual 5-7 day trek up to the ridge line, to various overwatch positions.
  The name of the mountain range escapes me, but what we named it will never make it past the emus.
  A mama-san or 3 would normally accompany our patrols, carrying large quantities of orangee soda bottles, wrapped in a tarp on their head. Their backpacks consisted of metal cooking bowls, chopsticks, etc, and… Ramen! Mama-sans’ ages? Probably in the 60s or 70s. It's hard to tell, as they were of farming origin, mostly from rice paddies and lots of vegetable farms. They were of very rugged countenance, to say the least.
  As steep as those mountains are, and as tired and sore we were, mama-san would walk seemingly upright, while smiling and nodding to us in encouragement. Her pace and her poise, while trudging past us, was humbling. It would quiet the complainers for a short while.

"OMG! I love your yoga mat! Did you make that?!"

"I did, thanks. It's jute so it's got great traction, and I made it thick so it's mad comfy."

"Bet! I'd love to experience a Hamsasana or Padmasana on it. Could you teach me to make one?"


Gah! I am so sick of wove culture!

(If you disagree, weave me out of it.)
A lot of proper nouns, abbrvs, and naticks, especially for a Monday. Felt half-hearted.

I found myself actually having to do math pre-coffee this morning. And en Español, no less! I thought they promised no math... (Don't get me started on LEMMA: all the commenters remembering it from high school math must be of a different generation than me. And have excellent memory from many decades ago!) 😜

And now I'm fixated on getting some DIM SUM, stat. There are still a few places with the trolleys, and I'm making a point to get to one this weekend! Now what to do about today... With this wet and windy weather, it's a perfect day for RAMEN from the shop down the street. Thanks for the suggestions, Katherine! I'll even forgive the early morning math! Very much looking forward to more puzzles from you. Congratulations on the debut! 🎊
Good job Katherine, although it took me a surprisingly long time to complete (for a Monday)!

I do count on being able to work the daily NYT crossword. Why am I unable to see online the answers to the version published in my local newspaper -- the Albuquerque Journal.  Much as I searched yesterday the answer grids were not for the one in my paper yesterday.  Mine was captioned "Central Perk" by Richard Katz
I did this on paper with a pencil and it was fun how that can slow me down. Good puzzle for a Monday, too!

I didn't do Saturday's puzzle in time to add to the comments, but thought that those of you who participated in the Pynchon discussion might be interested in this post (by, I admit, my son). I couldn't quite figure out how to make it readable, other than by re-copying the link into my browser. https://open.substack.com/pub/lamniformes/p/101025?utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=email

It is a credit to the Melting Pot that we call America, that DIM SUM is Monday-worthy:) Here's a couple of graceful birds--one Italian, one Austrian/German--moving, molto legato, across the musical pond: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lo9xLyzWA80&list=RDLo9xLyzWA80&start_radio=1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4_D2msi0wg&list=RDc4_D2msi0wg&start_radio=1
Was left with TA_ and LEM_A, so I just had to spam until it solved. Never heard of either word before today.

One more late puzzle find. Never seen another one like this either. A Sunday from April 29, 2018 by Peter Wentz with the title: "Mis-unabbreviated". A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Meadows filled with loos?" WATERCLOSETFIELDS "Where sailors recover from their injuries?" PHYSICALTHERAPYBOATS "Cry of devotion from a non-academy student?" PUBLICSCHOOLILOVEYOU "Morning zoo programming?" ANTEMERIDIEMRADIO And a couple of other theme answers: ADVANCEDPLACEMENTNEWS POLITICALLYCORRECTLAB Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/29/2018&g=100&d=A ...
Cograts Katherine on a challenging Monday pizzle! Hope you return.
This was awful, not just for a Monday but in general. Lazy clueing.
TIL that LEMMA has a meaning in linguistics. I'm a math person,so the puzzle's use was familiar to me.
Enjoyed the puzzle!

Oh this was fun! 
Despite a plethora of soft chewy foods (OATS, RAMEN, PUDDING), this puzzle was rather crunchy for a Monday!

I learned LEMMA and YOSHI today, and really appreciated SLIM. I hear your chances improve if you actually buy a ticket, but not by much. 
Thank you Katherine!

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Break the Hippocratic oath, say]  (2)(4)
[One might be ticked off]  (4)


DO HARM
LIST
@Lewis Great choices. Do you mind if I ask how you distinguish between  favorites and encore clues? Are the latter akin to honorable mentions?

Erik,

Look again. Lewis distinguishes between original clues and encore clues (the former never having appeared before in major crosswords).
@Barry Ancona Thanks for clarifying. I wasn't clear what original denoted in this context.

@Sean Peterson

And yet, I'd bet not 1 in a 1000 Americans, if asked to do so, could complete a NYT Monday crossword.

@Francis
Of course they could. They may not think they could because there's some mystique around the difficulty. I'm not all that smart but I work slowly and manage to figure them all out.

@Hanson

I don't think they see it as mystique.  

I think they see it as some sort of plot to exclude them.  They see it as something "the elite" do.

Maybe you could convince them otherwise.

@Francis
Sad to say, I’m sure you are right. Maybe even fewer…

@Francis 

I'd bet one in three could do a Monday puzzle.

@Bruce

I think I was pessimistic with one in 10000.

I'd probably feel better with one in a hundred.

But I can't go as far as one in three.

@Fact Boy

I always said that DIM SUM was what my paycheck looked like after all the deductions.

@Steve L

René Descarte, hankering for Chinese food: "Cogito ergo dim sum."

@Fact Boy
"Who ordered Chinese food?"

"You did. I asked what you wanted for lunch."

"No, no! It was a general comment about the weather.  I said, 'dim sun.'"

@Eric Hougland

My husband's employer once gave everyone in the office scratchers for Christmas. My husband, who isn't exactly known for tact, said, "Can you just give me the dollar?" It didn't win him any points at work! 😆

@Eric Hougland

Great song choice!

@sotto voce

Thanks!

@Manhattan

I think most people are familiar with it even for non-academics—public school teachers can get tenure, and you can use it in a looser sense as well—“his tenure as a congressman came to an end”.

@Manhattan 
I think TENURE is much more commonly know than the rather esoteric 70A. Not even our distinguished columnist recognized that one.
@Manhattan - Do you mean 70A ?   TIL lemma.  Tenure in 48D is a well-known word.

@Grumpy

Yes. I was about to say that!  Never heard of LEMMA until today. But I think most people have heard of TENURE
@SP - I should have been clearer.  I didn't mean that most non-academics wouldn't know the word 'tenure', but that they wouldn't know that was a goal of assistant professors.
@jennie - I should have been clearer.  I thought most non-academics wouldn't know that tenure was a goal of assistant professors, not that they wouldn't know the word 'tenure'.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Great theory, though.

Manhattan,

So you think non-academics would know the word "tenure" but would not know it was something sought by teachers?

OK, then.

Strudel Dad,

Bah!  Or is that baa?

@Strudel Dad,

Is that what’s called a Strudel Dad joke?

@Strudel Dad

The cruciverbalist’s lambent!

@Strudel Dad
“Shear stupidity”

@Strudel Dad
I think you're just reeling from the Jays' loss last night. Now, if they'd only worn cozy wool-knit uniforms and kept  the SkyDome roof open...well, the good news is that tonight's another game.

Let's go, Jays!
🐦🍁🐦⚾️🐦⚾️🐦🍁🐦

@SBK
And we’ll be there, cheering them on.  (After 37 years of being season — seasoned? —ticket-holders, we are hoping for our third — and final — happy outcome for the Jays, having been chased away by Rogers, who followed up this season’s 25% ticket-price increase with next season’s 150% ticket-price increase.)

@Strudel Dad

Those ticket prices are probably a prime example of the wealthy simply absorbing everything for themselves.

We'll eventually have empty stadiums but full luxury boxes.  If they can get all the money they want from their associates, why would they need fans?

Tax the Rich.

@Strudel Dad
Please, stop pulling the wool over my eyes.🐑

@Francis
Beats eating them!

CHOMP  
🍽
You're Cassandra; you explain it!

@Barry Ancona

Yes, a past master.

@Cassandra59
That has been happening to me often. Very frustrating. Like you, I have no idea why!

@SBK

Us reptilians do it to frustrate y'all.

@Terry

Did you see the puzzlemaker's comment, "For the record, I originally clued 3-Down as “Like MIT and Harvard,” but alas, the editors had other plans."? She is an MIT upperclassman (or upper class woman--but that sounds like somebody at the dinner table in Downton Abbey). 

I remember exactly when, where, and from whom I learned the word "lemma" (fall of 10th grade, NW corner 2nd floor of my highschool, Rodney St Dizier, my geometry teacher.

On the other hand, I never saw the or heard the word "DimSum" until I did this crossword puzzle.

@Mark
Some people have mentioned having issues, but haven't been very clear about what their issues are.  Do you the Games app? If you haven't already tried, maybe uninstall and reinstall?

@Mark

Switch over to an Android.
@EJ. For your stats try looking for the “me” icon. They are hiding behind there.
@EJ.   Thanks.     I appreciate your help.

@EJ
I use the NYT app on my IPad, and I’ve been going through Sections to More in Games to get to Wordplay/stats/archives since this problem started last week.
@coloradoz Slim Pickens and Sister Jeanne?

@coloradoz 

Are there male nuns?

@Seb

Well, that's only  because you're in a weird part of the world.

In fact, some of your news sources actually refer to Asia as "the weird part of the world".

I sense we in the west are in for a pretty profound and unpleasant awakening.

@Francis

Terrible Mistake:  

"In fact, some of your news sources actually refer to Asia as "the weird part of the world"."

should be 

"In fact some of *our* new sources ..."

I did not mean to demean Australian new sources.

@Francis

ROFL! No diplomatic appointments for you, Francis -- even under your current ruler!

@Francis
ROFL! 
No diplomatic appointments for you, Francis -- not even under your current ruler!
😂
😂
😂
@Joe P So does CHICKENRAMEN.
@Joe P Yep, that was one of my first fills and it slowed me down for a bit!

@Joe P
I went with RAMENNOODLES until crosses forced it out.
@Jacqui J  why would you use any other name than your “maiden “ name.  are you owned by your marital partner?

@pedant O that is very judgemental. I am feminist to the core and have been since I was a little child. I chose to use my hubby's name because (1) I liked it better than my maiden name; (2) My maiden name was from my father who was NOT feminist, whereas my husband is feminist. The deal is that we get to choose.

@Francis

How could they have consented if there was no discussion? Unless you meant tacit consent (to some stereotype). Did you ask and they agreed? Did they decide to take your name and you never talked about it?

@pedant

What a ridiculous insinuation to pose to someone. This is what you bring to a crossword puzzle comment board? Stop trolling.

@pedant

Everyone else has already made excellent points, so I will simply add this.  🙄

@Jacqui J to answer pedant’s question, my maiden name is now my middle name. I chose to take my husband’s name because it’s shorter and easier to pronounce. And it flows better with my first name. I like the alliteration. And thank you to everyone that came to my defense…it was indeed a ridiculous question.

@HeathieJ that’s exactly what I did. Officially I have two middle names, but they wouldn’t let me use both for my passport because my names are too long. So just my maiden name  is listed for middle now 😏

@Patrick J.
like stigma and schema and others...
@Patrick J.  And, @Sam, a dilemma is literally two lemmate.

@Patrick J.
Cmon everyone knows the plural of LEMMA is LEMMINGS.

@Patrick J.

LEMMAE!
@Patrick J. Editors please edit out any MATH stuff. This  puzzle is about WORDS.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Words are what people use to communicate with each other.

Math is what the universe uses to communicate with us.

I've decided.

@Francis
You might enjoy a book called, "Is God a Mathematician?" by Mario Livio. He is a science popularizer, esp. in maths, and this book addresses the delightful question, Do we invent or discover mathematics? Maths elements here are pretty accessible to non-mathists and it's a great discussion of a very serious question. Enjoy.

@Andrzej

😆You kill me, dude.
@Francis Having read Maths and Philosophy, I can confirm that those two views can be called Platonism and Intuitionism and that they (and other approaches) were taught to me at uni.

@John

As a Stanford alum (graduate level) I take offense at that.

I'm only kidding.

I think.
@John. But Sheldon turned MIT down.
@Francis Hunter College  for me, and, for my nephew,  Columbia University.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

That's the kind of clue that is 100% certain to make people irritable.

@Francis

I'll never see Wydział Prawa i Administracji Uniwersytetu Warszawskiego clued at the NYT😂

@Andrzej

And I'll never see Southern Colorado State College, which is were I got my undergraduate degree.

@Andrzej
How small was the print on your athletic jerseys?!?
*a* great romp

@sotto voce

Not sure if this is it, but there’s a theatrical club at Harvard called the Hasty Pudding club and they give an award every year to an actor, it’s pretty well known maybe that’s it?

@Rachel

I’d recommend diving into the archives. Maybe jump back to 2020, which is recent enough that the trivia doesn’t feel dated and gives you 5 years of puzzles to play with.
@Petrol EDYS 🙂
@Petrol  That's a great list.  I would only add "acai", which we probably eat after all those reps and sets. Less common and not as tasty: roe, ghee, oleo

@Petrol

You missed “sloe” (berries or gin fizzes, my high school mixed drink of choice), and “soya” .
@Petrol Emu and goat
@jas and chai and tiramasu

@Petrol

What a diet! 😆 Just don’t forget the ALE to wash it all down!

@Petrol
Apparently everything includes a generous portion of LEEKS, EDAM and MAYO
@Heidi The ale almost always being of the Indian pale variety.

@Petrol
Pretty much everything worth having....

@Mean Old Lady
I hope it was clear I was answering Petrol's query:  "What did I miss?"

@Heidi
A local brewery here in Portland used to offer a variety called Hampshire Pale Ale during the winter months and its slogan was "available only when the weather sucks" - needless to say, it was brewed for several months each year!❄️😜

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
I actually thought it was a great clue - and I rarely run across many that impress me 🤷‍♀️

@Jane Wheelaghan

I wish it had been lake.  

You may not be familiar with the "Mall of America" in the Twin Cities.

It is enormous.  It is impressive.  It was something I just had to see when I first came here in 2003.  And, in all honesty, it was a structure unlike anything I've ever seen--a multi-story shopping area with a fairly impressive set of roller coasters and other rides in the middle.  A midway in the middle of a shopping mall.

I haven't been there in years, though.

When I first got here, it was possible to find a book store in the Mall of America.  It was possible to buy a baseball or a catcher's mitt in the Mall of America.  It was possible to buy a football at the Mall of America.

Now you can't do any of that (at least as of 10 years ago).  Now you can only *look* like a baseball player by buying an overpriced MLB hat.  You can't actually buy anything that might get you to getting your own free hat by being hired by an MLB team.

I'm actually surprised the Mall of America is still relevant.  Malls have essentially disappeared in America, like local newspapers.  The Mall of America is the New York Times of malls. 

The last of a dying breed.

If you'll allow me a personal moment.  

One moment I'll always remember with my granddaughter, who was 4 at the time.  The conversation went something like this:

Me:  I think you're a rascal.
Her:  I am not a rascal.
Me:  Oh, I'm pretty sure you're a rascal.
Her. I am NOT a rascal.
Me:  You're a rascally rabbit.
Her:  I AM NOT A RASCAL.
Her: (after some thought) What's a rascal?
 
This was a real gift to me.

I don't know, MOA still has a lot of fun and unique things. They've got the aquarium and the theme parks, they've got plenty of FAST FOODS, but also some fine dining. They still have a number of unique stores. Plenty of fun entertainment and family activities. And even though the bookstores I think only Barnes & Noble there now, that's about as good as you get these days with Amazon taking over the book world. You can still find them, but the independent bookstores are definitely not in plentitude. Funny, because I just watched You G ot Mail on the plane n the way over here...  

I don't get me wrong, I haven't been there in a few years and I only go when someone from out of town comes and they want to see it, but I do still see it as relevant and as for other malls, I actually live in Roseville and the Rosedale Mall is booming, the whole area is really getting built up It's a little annoying because you know traffic and what not. Hey kids, get outta my yard!!  Last time I went into that mall was maybe a few months ago when I was for their Potluck food court had a taco place we wanted to try out. Most of their little restaurants in there are independent places or a very small local only chains. 

Never have been a mall girl myself though.

@Jerry

The storm tracked further east than expected so the very high winds and heavy rain was not as bad as expected.   

It's a flooding event with major flooding on the barrier islands with this afternoon's high tide at 2 PM.  Some areas will see 2 feet or more of water over minor flood levels.  

Significant beach erosion is also occurring.   

For areas that flood regularly this has become fairly routine and folks adapt.  There were some tourists around this weekend and they had to be coached on how to handle and where to move their cars.

  Long story short, by the time we'd reach our destination for the one hour rest, the small cooking fires were ablaze, and the ramen was ready to serve. Then, they'd pack it all up and meet us at the next overwatch.
  That was my first introduction to ramen, and memories like those still remain. Even to this day, I prepare my home cooked ramen gourmet style. I still savor those $.012 packages of comfort, with my added gourmet enhancements.
